query: need CRM solution provider for business operations
content: What is CRM? CRM = Customer Relationship Management. •	It’s both a strategy and a software tool used to manage customer interactions. •	Companies use CRM systems (like Salesforce, HubSpot, Zoho, or even Excel-based systems) to track clients, sales leads, communications, contracts, follow-ups, and after-sales service. •	For a Business Development Officer, CRM is essential because: •	You log new client leads. •	Track who you contacted, when, and about what. •	Set reminders for follow-ups. •	Monitor the sales pipeline (prospects → proposals → closed deals). •	Keep customer history (orders, complaints, pricing preferences). •	Management can see your performance metrics (number of calls, meetings, sales closed, revenue generated).

content: CRM stands for Customer Relationship Management. In simple words 👇 It’s a system or software that helps businesses manage and improve relationships with their customers. 💡 Example: When a company uses CRM software (like Salesforce, HubSpot, or Zoho CRM), they can: •	Save all customer contact details in one place 📇 •	Track customer interactions (calls, emails, chats, etc.) 📞💬 •	Follow up with leads and customers on time ⏰ •	Analyze customer behavior and sales trends 📊 🎯 Main Purpose: To improve customer service, increase sales, and keep customers happy. 🧩 In short: CRM = Tool to manage customers, leads, and sales efficiently.

content: CRM and online charging systems (OCS) have two different database table structures based on the business behind them and the calling APIs. Based on my experience, • CRM database has a lower-level normalizing than OCS, which helps to be better at providing reporting UI. • OCS databases are separated into two kinds: - Unstructured memory databases to provide high demand and fast response to major business requests, such as subscriber status, remaining credit limits, keeping up-to-date account usage details, etc. - Structured physical databases to support OCS UI, keep the transactions, payment records, etc. Both UIs call the API to return information and modify data in the tables.

content: Not sure whether to choose ERP or CRM? Here's a quick breakdown of their key differences! 1. What is ERP? ERP systems manage core business functions like finance, supply chain, and HR, streamlining internal operations across departments. 2. What is CRM? CRM focuses on managing customer relationships, enhancing sales, marketing, and customer service by organizing customer interactions and data. 3. Internal vs Customer-Centric ERP is designed for internal business operations, while CRM centers on improving customer interactions and driving sales growth. 4. Data Management ERP manages transactional data like finances and inventory, while CRM organizes customer-centric data, including contacts and purchase history. 5. Functionality ERP supports business processes like finance and procurement, while CRM boosts customer engagement by organizing sales and service data. 6. Use Case ERP is typically used across the entire organization, whereas CRM is mainly for sales, marketing, and customer service teams. 7. Integration ERP integrates with systems like supply chain and financial tools, while CRM connects with email marketing, social media, and customer support platforms. hashtag # learnandearn Check https://lnkd.in/dxbZdz_3

⏰ Most software RFPs fail - not because of poor process, but because of poor timing. I see this all the time: a team runs an RFP three-six months before a renewal for a deeply embedded software (for example an ERP or CRM). Sure, the vendor might shave a bit off the price to “play the game”, but let’s be honest: they know you can’t switch in time. And they’ll hang that over you. Because when your system is deeply embedded, processes, data, integrations, user training, three months isn’t negotiation leverage, it’s a deadline trap. Now imagine this: the recommended migration timeline for a CRM is 9–12 months (yes, it really is - Virtuous outlines this perfectly here https://lnkd.in/e-GYTAAJ ). You start an RFP then. Suddenly, the balance shifts. That’s not a “let’s see if we can get 5% off” move. That’s “we have the time, plan, and runway to actually change vendors.” Because this isn’t just a bluff anymore. This is a credible exit plan! hashtag # Procurement hashtag # SoftwareProcurement hashtag # RFP hashtag # VendorManagement hashtag # SoftwareOptimization hashtag # StrategicSourcing hashtag # SpendSmarter hashtag # TechSpend hashtag # ProcurementInsights hashtag # CostControl

content: Hiring dedicated developers vs. project-based outsourcing - what's better for your startup? “Should I hire a dedicated team or just outsource my project?” - a founder once asked me. I have seen both. Project-based works great for short-term goals - build fast, deliver, move on. But for long-term products, it falls short. You lose context, continuity, and ownership. When you hire a dedicated team, they grow with your product. They remember decisions, avoid repeated mistakes, and build like owners. One of our startup clients switched from project outsourcing to a dedicated model - Within 2 months, bugs dropped, delivery time improved, and founder stress went down. Lesson: You don’t just need developers. You need partners who live your product daily. If that’s what you’re building, let’s connect. hashtag # DedicatedTeam hashtag # StartupGrowth hashtag # Outsourcing hashtag # ProductDevelopment hashtag # DedicatedDeveloper

content: 3 mistakes SaaS founders make when outsourcing development Outsourcing is supposed to save time but for many founders, it turns into a headache. After working with several SaaS startups, we’ve noticed the same 3 patterns repeat: 1️⃣ No clear ownership. Founders hire a team but skip defining who owns what. The result? Confusion, missed deadlines, and finger-pointing. 2️⃣ Fuzzy documentation. Even the best developers can’t fix unclear requirements. A one-line Jira ticket like “improve dashboard speed” isn’t enough. 3️⃣ No overlap in communication. If you’re in the US and your dev team is in India, communication windows matter. A daily 20-min sync can prevent weeks of rework. The fix? 👉 Define ownership. 👉 Write problem-focused requirements. 👉 Communicate predictably. When done right, outsourcing isn’t a compromise, it’s leverage. We help SaaS startups set up dev processes that actually work across time zones. DM if you’re exploring outsourcing for the first time.

"𝗕𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲𝘁: 250.0 USD - 750.0 USD 𝗧𝗶𝘁𝗹𝗲: CRM Website Enhancement Current Website is: Code Igniter PHP / MYSQL Javascript Access files through Cyberpanel Hosted on Hostlinger We have a functional website that operates as a CRM (Customer Relationship Manager) and needs 3 changes. If bidding please bid based on completing one, two or all three of these requirements and inform me what your choice is in your bid. If you require backend access before bidding please request it and I can provide the access. I will only meet with the successful bidder(s) if needed or desired, not during the bidding process. First Item: The current system has a single payment function which is connected to Stripe currently. We need to change the single payment function to monthly subscription payments. This may also need to involve changes to our Stripe set up (which we can handle if needed). This will also need to include the ability to cancel the subscription, upgrade the subscription, downgrade the subscription in the logged in area for the user. The admin area will also need to have the ability to fully manage subscriptions. Second item: The current system only allows users to add leads or customers one at a time. We need to add a csv upload option for leads and customers. There needs to be a button when a user is logged in that also allows for multiple records (lead or customer) to be added at once by uploading a CSV. There will also need to be a sample CSV the User can download so they can see the proper format to upload a CSV in. Third item: The current system only allows for manual entry of contacts into the system. We need to allow for Integration with Google email contacts or Microsoft email contacts. There may be an API that allows for this. When a contact is added to the users email platform there needs to be an automatic upload of that contact to the CRM. There would also need to be a mechanism in the CRM to connect the email platform to the CRM and allow the contacts to transfer automatically.
